title: Elasticity of Demand for Golf Balls

content.question: When Tom’s income increases from <math alttext="$100" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>100</mn></math> to <math alttext="$120" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>120</mn></math>, the quantity of golf balls he purchases increases from <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is Tom’s income elasticity of demand, and what type of good is a golf ball for Tom?

choices.label: Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and golf balls are a normal good for Tom.
Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="negative 1" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, and golf balls are an inferior good for Tom.
Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="10" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn></math>, and golf balls are a normal good for Tom.
Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="negative 10" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, and golf balls are an inferior good for Tom.
Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="20" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math>, and golf balls are a normal good for Tom.

content.answer: Income elasticity of demand is <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and golf balls are a normal good for Tom.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Interpret a specific economic outcome using quantitative data or calculations.
